title: Children who missed receiving the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) will be able to get it from next week.
content: Over 1.46 million children born between April 2016 and October 2018 will be inoculated with inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) during a nationwide immunisation drive starting next Sunday.Officials said, children who missed the IPV vaccine during the routine immunisation programme will be administered the vaccine, as they are at risk of getting infected with Type-2 polio.“All necessary preparations regarding IPV vaccination to the children deprived of the vaccine are being completed,” said Dr Abhiyan Gautam, chief of the Immunisation Section at the Family Welfare Division under the Department of Health Services. “The vaccine will be administered in schools, booths and health posts.”Nepal has been polio-free since 2010, but was officially declared polio-free by the World Health Organisation on March 27, 2014, after maintaining zero polio cases for three consecutive years.After introducing the IPV vaccine in September 2014, the country switched to the bivalent oral poliovirus vaccine (bOPV0) from the trivalent oral poliovirus vaccine (tOPV). The trivalent oral poliovirus vaccine contains all three types of poliovirus: Type-1, Type-2, and Type-3. The current oral poliovirus vaccine is made up of live, attenuated poliovirus. The trivalent poliovirus vaccine was effective against all three types of poliovirus. However, the Type -2 component of this vaccine can lead to the circulation of vaccine-derived viruses. Its use was linked to a vaccine associated with paralytic polio, a condition in which children develop paralysis.Nepal became the first country in the South Asia region to incorporate the IPV vaccine in its routine immunisation programme in line with the UN Health body’s endgame strategic plan to eliminate the risk of vaccine-derived poliovirus and phase out all oral polio vaccines in the routine immunisation programme.IPV consists of inactivated poliovirus strains of all three poliovirus types.Gautam said that due to global shortages of the IPV vaccine, children born between April 13, 2016, and October 18, 2018, were inoculated only with the bivalent oral poliovirus vaccine.“Children who missed the IPV vaccine will be at high risk of poliovirus infection,” warned Gautam. “So we are launching a campaign to inoculate them.”Health Officials say that children should continuously receive the bivalent poliovirus vaccine, even if they are administered the IPV vaccine, as the bivalent poliovirus vaccine is also necessary for intestinal immunity, while IPV provides mucosal immunity.Childhood immunisation is the number one priority of the government, under which 13 types of vaccines are given against a range of diseases, including measles-rubella, pneumonia, tuberculosis, diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, rotavirus, Japanese encephalitis and typhoid under the regular immunisation programme, free of cost.Regular immunisation is one of the most successful programmes in Nepal, with a high coverage rate. The country has demonstrated remarkable progress in reducing the under-five mortality rate and the regular immunisation programme is credited with that.The Nepal Demographic and Health Survey-2022 carried out by the Ministry of Health and Population, however, showed that at least four percent of the children aged between 12 and 23 months received no vaccine at all. This figure was one percent in 2016.The Ministry of Health and Population said that the vaccine coverage rate for polio is 95 throughout the country.
summary: Over 1.46 million children born between 2016 and 2018 will receive inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) during a nationwide immunization drive, bringing Nepal closer to eliminating the risk of vaccine-derived poliovirus.

title: Nepali cuisine is making a mark in New York City. Restaurants are serving traditional dishes like momos and thukpa, as well as new fusion creations. New Yorkers are enjoying the unique flavors and spices of Nepali food.
content:
**Aditya Mishra's Journey as a Nepali Chef in New York City**

Aditya Mishra, a Nepali chef, came to New York to pursue his passion for cooking. He believes in elevating Nepali cuisine globally.

**The Sewing Tin**

Mishra and his partner founded "The Sewing Tin" restaurant to create a personal and communal dining experience that tells stories through food. The menu features dishes that blend Nepali and Indian flavors.

**Promoting Nepali Cuisine Abroad**

Mishra aims to share Nepali food worldwide by serving traditional dishes like kachaila and chatamari. He hopes to introduce more people to the unique flavors of Nepal.

**Challenges and Criticism**

As an outsider in New York, Mishra faced challenges but embraced the opportunities to share his culture. He believes that chefs should be encouraged to be creative and not be discouraged by criticism.

**Signature Dish: Confit Duck Chatamari**

Mishra's signature dish combines traditional Nepali chatamari with French confit duck. The dish features duck cooked in duck fat, topped with garlic aioli, pickled onions, and scallions.
summary: Aditya Mishra, a Nepali chef based in New York City, is pioneering Nepali cuisine globally through his supper club "The Sewing Tin," promoting authentic Nepali flavors while blending them with modern culinary techniques, despite facing challenges as an outsider in the bustling city.

title: Patience and passion are key ingredients in the art of baking pastries.
content:
Celeus Baral, a 21-year-old environmental science student, started baking during the pandemic. She runs Bakeleus, an online baking shop, where she makes and sells various baked goods like jams, tarts, cakes, and cookies.

Baral believes baking is a precise science that requires patience. Her environmental background influences her baking, as she incorporates produce she grows herself and emphasizes zero-waste.

Despite being a full-time student, she takes orders with a minimum of 72 hours' notice. She's passionate about her baking and infuses it with love.

Here are some easy recipes from Bakeleus to try at home:

**Mini Carrot Cakes**

* Ingredients: flour, spices, baking powder, salt, eggs, sugar, vanilla, oil, carrots, walnuts, cream cheese, butter, salt, powdered sugar
* Instructions: Whisk dry ingredients, beat eggs and sugar, mix in oil, milk, flour, carrots, and walnuts. Bake and cool. Make frosting by beating butter, cream cheese, vanilla, and salt, then adding sugar. Frost cakes and decorate.

**Mulberry Fudge Cake**

* Ingredients: eggs, sugar, butter, chocolate, yogurt, flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, baking powder, mulberries, chopped walnuts
* Instructions: Beat eggs and sugar, melt butter and chocolate and add, mix in yogurt, cocoa powder, flour, baking powder. Add half the mulberries and walnuts. Pour into greased dish and bake. Top with ice cream and mulberries.

**Strawberry Casserole**

* Ingredients: yogurt, cream cheese, milk, honey, vanilla, flour, sugar, salt, fresh strawberries, almond flakes
* Instructions: Blend ingredients until smooth, pour into lined baking pan, top with strawberries and almond flakes. Bake until cooked. Serve hot with ice cream or whipped cream.
summary: Celeus Baral, an environment science student, runs the online baking shop Bakeleus, where she sells a variety of baked goods made with produce she grows herself, promoting gratitude for nature and advocating for zero-waste practices.

title:
**Potato: Know Your Food**

Potatoes are a versatile vegetable that comes in various shapes, sizes, and colors. They are a good source of:

* Carbohydrates (energy)
* Potassium (heart health)
* Vitamin C (immunity)

**Types of Potatoes:**

* **Russet:** Ideal for baking and frying
* **Yukon Gold:** Creamy and flavorful, perfect for mashing
* **Red:** Firm and waxy, good for roasting and salads

**Selection and Storage:**

* Choose potatoes that are firm and smooth.
* Avoid potatoes with sprouts or cuts.
* Store potatoes in a cool, dark place to prevent them from sprouting.

**Health Benefits:**

* Potatoes contain antioxidants that help protect the body from damage.
* They are a low-fat, low-calorie food that can help with weight management.
* Potatoes are naturally gluten-free.
content:
**Potato: A Versatile and Nutritious Staple Food**

* Potatoes are widely consumed in Nepal, especially in mountainous areas.
* They are low in fat and high in nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and fiber.
* Potatoes provide potassium, copper, vitamin C, and dietary fiber.
* They are grown in various climatic conditions and can withstand climate change.
* Different types of potatoes include red, white, dark, and sweet potatoes.
* Potatoes have health benefits like reducing blood pressure, cholesterol, and the risk of heart disease.
* They contain fiber, which supports digestive health.
* Processed potato products like chips and fries are popular but should be consumed in moderation due to high calories and potential nutrient loss.
* Potatoes can be cooked in various ways to retain their nutrients.
summary: Potatoes, a versatile staple food in Nepal, provide numerous nutrients, including vitamins, minerals, and fiber; their cultivation spans diverse climates and includes imports of chips, frozen, and fresh varieties, while consumption benefits heart, digestive, and overall health, though moderation is advised for diabetics and chips/fries due to calorie intake.

title:
**Eggs: A Nutritional Powerhouse**

Eggs are highly nutritious, containing:

* **Protein:** Essential for building and repairing tissues.
* **Vitamins:** Rich in A, D, B12, and folate.
* **Minerals:** Excellent source of iron, calcium, and zinc.
* **Antioxidants:** Protect cells from damage.
* **Low in calories:** Only about 70 calories per large egg.

Eggs are a versatile food that can be enjoyed in various ways:

* Fried
* Scrambled
* Boiled
* Baked
* In salads or sandwiches

Regular consumption of eggs supports overall health, including:

* Healthy heart
* Strong bones
* Improved brain function
* Weight management
content:
**Chicken Eggs: Superfood with Many Benefits**

Chicken eggs are healthy, full of nutrients like vitamins and minerals. They are affordable and a complete source of protein.

**Benefits of Eating Eggs:**

* Weight loss
* Lower blood pressure
* Protect against infections

**Sourcing Eggs in Nepal:**

Nepal produces enough eggs for its own needs. Eggs are available in two sizes: big and medium.

**Types of Eggs:**

* Pastured eggs: From free-range chickens, higher in nutrients but more expensive.
* Omega-3-enriched eggs: Contain more Omega-3 fatty acids, which are good for the heart.

**How Many Eggs to Eat:**

Healthy adults can eat 1-2 eggs per day.

**Quality of Eggs:**

There is no government agency checking the quality of eggs sold in Nepal. However, studies in other countries have found antibiotic resistance in chicken eggs.

**Other Benefits of Eggs:**

* Help with weight loss
* Strengthen bones in pregnant women
* Improve skin health
* Lower risk of stroke
* Protect against eye diseases
* Support brain development in babies
summary: Eggs, rich in nutrients and affordable, provide a complete protein source and offer numerous health benefits including weight loss, reduced blood pressure, and protection against infections, with pastured eggs providing additional Omega-3 benefits.

title: Piano Piano South offers authentic Italian cuisine in a lively and welcoming atmosphere.
content:
**Piano Piano South**

Piano Piano South is a relaxing Italian restaurant in Bakhundole, Lalitpur. It has indoor and outdoor seating with a charming garden dining area. The restaurant has a soothing atmosphere with piano music and offers a revised menu with diverse Italian dishes curated by chef Sujan Poudel.

The Antipasti section offers dishes like Tomato Soup Shots, Bruschetta Caprese, and Calamari Fritti. Main courses include Ravioli Prosciutto and Ricotta, and Pasta Con Calamari E Gamberi. Desserts include Tiramisu and Torta Al Cioccolato. The restaurant has a curated wine selection that pairs well with the Italian fare.

The restaurant is a great place for solitary reflections and quality family time. It provides a peaceful and quiet ambiance in a vibrant city.
summary: Piano Piano South, an Italian restaurant in Lalitpur, offers a serene ambiance, a revised menu with Italian flavors, a curated wine selection, and delicate dishes like Creamy Tomato Soup and Prosciutto with Slow-Roasted Tomatoes and Eggplant, creating a culinary haven and a sanctuary for relaxation.

title:
**Places to Visit in Nepal in 2024:**

* **Kathmandu:** Bustling capital with ancient temples and cultural heritage.
* **Pokhara:** Stunning lakeside city with panoramic mountain views.
* **Chitwan National Park:** Home to a variety of wildlife, including rhinos and tigers.
* **Bhaktapur:** Historic city with well-preserved architecture and crafts.
* **Lumbini:** Birthplace of Lord Buddha, a sacred pilgrimage site.
* **Sagarmatha National Park (Everest Region):** Explore the iconic Mount Everest.
* **Langtang Valley:** Scenic trekking trail with stunning views of the Himalayas.
content:
**Mundhum Trek**
- Cultural walk in eastern Nepal
- Around 4,200 metres high
- Scenic views of mountain peaks
- Spring season recommended

**Janaki Mandir**
- Largest temple in Nepal
- Dedicated to Sita from Hindu mythology
- Wedding anniversary celebrated annually

**Kuri Village**
- Tourist destination with snowy landscapes
- Located high on a mountain
- Best visited for snowfall from December to March

**Annapurna Base Camp**
- Short and budget-friendly trek
- Takes you to the base of the Annapurna South peak
- Offers cultural diversity and scenic views
- Best time to trek is spring or autumn

**Bardiya National Park**
- Home to the Royal Bengal Tiger
- Also has elephants, rhinos, and dolphins
- Visit during mid-September to mid-December or mid-February to May

**Khaptad National Park**
- Protected area in western Nepal
- Known for its pristine wilderness
- Visit during spring or autumn for ideal weather
summary: Mundhum Trek, Annapurna Base Camp, Janaki Mandir, Kuri Village, Bardiya National Park, Khaptad National Park, and Limi Valley offer captivating cultural experiences, picturesque treks, wildlife encounters, and scenic beauty in Nepal's diverse regions.

title:
**Phidim**

Past memories and present realities coexist in Phidim. It carries its rich history and traditions while embracing modern developments.
content:
Writer's heart fills with joy upon returning to Phidim, his hometown, which has changed over the years.

Phidim has transformed from mud and stone houses to concrete buildings, leaving the writer with nostalgic memories.

The writer reflects on his childhood in Phidim, visiting his old school and remembering his love for literature.

Despite its modernization, Phidim faces challenges due to a lack of higher education and specialized healthcare, leading to an exodus of people.

The writer notes the influx of pilgrims to the nearby Pathibhara Devi Temple and reflects on Phidim's transition from a rustic town to a transit hub.

Leaving Phidim, the writer cherishes the memories of his hometown while acknowledging the inevitability of change.
summary: The author's hometown, Phidim, has undergone a significant transformation, transitioning from a traditional town to a modern hub, while still holding onto its cherished memories and facing challenges of urbanization and population exodus.

title: Architecture and art combined, creating a synergy of design and aesthetics.
content:
**Bara Imambara: A Wonder in Lucknow**

Lucknow welcomes you with a sign that says, "Smile, you're in Lucknow." The city lives up to this promise with its bustling streets and delicious food.

At Bara Imambara, built in 1784, you'll find:

* **Rumi Darwaza:** The grand entrance with its cream-colored mosque and intricate designs.
* **Asafi Hall:** A massive, pillarless hall that seems to stretch forever. It houses Asaf-ud-Daula's tomb.
* **Bhool Bhulaiyaa:** A confusing labyrinth above the hall with echoes that carry sounds throughout.
* **Roof:** A high point with a breathtaking view of the city.
* **Shahi Baoli:** An underground stepwell with intricate carvings and a unique feature that allowed people to watch visitors without being seen.

Bara Imambara is a testament to the architectural brilliance and the rich history of Lucknow.
summary: Bara Imambara, built during a famine for public employment, features an impressive main hall (Asafi Hall) without pillars or beams, a labyrinth (Bhool Bhulaiyaa) known for its echoing whispers, and a subterranean royal stepwell (Shahi Baoli) with ingenious temperature regulation and a well that doubles as a discreet surveillance tool.

title:
Trekking and Trails

Enjoy breathtaking treks and hikes on scenic trails. Explore diverse landscapes, encounter unique wildlife, and immerse yourself in nature's wonders.
content:
**Mountain Climbing Tips**

**Preparation:**

* Stay positive and believe you can do it.
* Start preparing a month before with exercises like walking and stretching.

**Essentials:**

* Pack light and warm clothing, including a down jacket, hat, sunglasses, and gloves.
* Bring a safety knife and period supplies.

**Challenges:**

* Altitude sickness: rest if symptoms occur, carry painkillers.
* Communication: talk to fellow trekkers and guides for support.
* Female trekkers may face underestimation.

**Becoming a Guide:**

* Join a trekking association and take a guide course.
* Develop skills in map reading, navigation, and safety measures.
* College programs in mountaineering are also available.

title:
**Solo Travel in Nepal**

* **Safety:** Nepal is generally safe for solo travelers, especially women.
* **Best Time to Visit:** Spring (March-May) and autumn (September-November) for trekking and sightseeing.
* **Getting Around:** Hire a guide or porter for treks; use public buses or taxis for short distances.
* **Accommodation:** Hostels and guesthouses offer affordable options.
* **Food:** Try traditional dishes like dal bhat (lentil soup with rice) and momos (dumplings).
* **Trekking:** Nepal offers world-renowned treks, such as the Everest Base Camp Trek and Annapurna Circuit.
* **Other Activities:** Visit ancient temples, explore lush valleys, and interact with friendly locals.
* **Tips:** Stay connected, respect local customs, and be prepared for altitude sickness.
content:
**Women-owned outdoor platform empowers female travelers**

**Duluwa Outdoors:**

* Organization founded by five women in 2021.
* Platform encourages and empowers women to travel independently.
* Connects women through social media and shared experiences.

**Solo travel in Nepal:**

* Nepal is generally safe for solo travelers.
* Solo travel is common for both foreign and Nepali women.
* Examples include women traveling between their homes and parents' homes.

**Tips for solo travel in Nepal:**

* Plan your itinerary and research transportation, lodging, and activities.
* Consider your fitness level and prepare for potential risks.
* Budget wisely and have an emergency fund.

**Safety tips:**

* Trust your instincts and be aware of your surroundings.
* Inform loved ones of your whereabouts, especially in areas without cell service.
* Be cautious of wildlife and natural disasters.
* Consider taking a wilderness first aid course.
summary: Five young women founded Duluwa Outdoors in 2021, an organization encouraging women to travel solo in Nepal, sharing safety tips and providing a platform for women to connect.

title: Nepal's former cricket captain Sandeep Lamichhane has been denied a US visa again.
content:
Nepal's cricketer Sandeep Lamichhane's hopes to play in the 2024 T20 World Cup have suffered a setback. The US Embassy in Kathmandu has denied him a visa for the second time, making it unlikely he will participate.

Lamichhane, a leg spinner, was initially denied a visa last week. The Embassy said it could not comment on individual visa cases.

Despite efforts from the Nepalese government and cricket officials, the Embassy has not changed its decision.

Lamichhane's supporters have expressed disappointment and taken to the streets to protest the visa denial.

Nepal's cricket team had submitted a list of 14 players to the ICC, leaving one slot open for Lamichhane if he received a visa. However, with his visa denial, the team will likely play the World Cup without him.
summary: Despite diplomatic efforts, Nepal's leg spinner Sandeep Lamichhane's US visa has been rejected twice, potentially ending his chances of participating in the 2024 ICC Men's T20 World Cup.

title: Nepal trains hard for upcoming cricket match against the United States.
content:
Nepal will face the US in a warm-up match in Dallas before the T20 World Cup.

Nepal's team has been practicing, including player Dipendra Singh Airee who recently recovered from an ankle injury.

Nepal lost their previous warm-up match to Canada but is preparing to face the US next.

The warm-up match against the US will help Nepal become familiar with the field where they will play the Netherlands in the World Cup.

The US will play Nepal in their first warm-up match before the World Cup.
summary: Nepal to face the United States in their final warmup match for the 2024 ICC Men’s T20 World Cup, with Dipendra Airee returning to the squad.

title: Canada highlighted Nepal's weakness in batting before the World Cup, exposing their lack of preparation and need for improvement.
content:
**Nepal's T20 World Cup Preparations Hit by Batting Woes in Warm-Up Loss to Canada**

Nepal's batting struggled as they lost their first warm-up match against Canada by 63 runs.

Despite qualifying for the 2024 T20 World Cup, Nepal's batting has been inconsistent since the start of the year.

Canada scored 183-7, with Nicholas Kriton (50) and Ravinderpal Singh (41) leading the way.

Nepal's chase was hampered by poor batting, with only Anil Sah (24) and Dipendra Singh Airee (37*) making significant contributions.

Nepal's next warm-up match is against the United States on Thursday. They begin the World Cup on June 4 against the Netherlands.
summary: Nepal's inconsistent batting hinders their warm-up for the 2024 ICC Men's T20 World Cup, despite victories in 2023 that included Asia Cup qualification and a whirlwind century from Malla.

title: Lamichhane's US visa status remains pending.
content: Nepali cricketer, Sandeep Lamichhane, may join the Nepal squad for the Cricket World Cup if he gets a visa for the United States. The Cricket Association of Nepal (CAN) submitted a list of 14 players to the International Cricket Council (ICC), leaving a spot for Lamichhane. After being acquitted of rape charges, Lamichhane is now allowed to play in international cricket tournaments. CAN hopes he will be granted a visa and can join the team. If not, the 15 players currently in the team will play in the World Cup. Nepal will start their World Cup against the Netherlands on June 4th.
summary: Nepal's cricket team submits 14 players to the ICC for the World Cup, leaving a spot open for Sandeep Lamichhane if he obtains a US visa.

content:

title: north-korea-sends-600-more-trash-balloons-over-border-south-says
content: North Korea sent some 600 balloons carrying trash into South Korea overnight, Seoul said on Sunday, in Pyongyang’s latest move to rile its rival neighbour.The balloons carrying garbage such as cigarette butts, cloth, paper waste and plastic were found across the capital from 8 p.m. to 10 a.m. (1100 GMT on Saturday to 0100 GMT on Sunday), South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff said.It said the military was monitoring the starting point and conducting aerial reconnaissance to track down and collect the balloons, which have large bags of trash suspended beneath them.North Korea on Wednesday sent hundreds of balloons carrying trash and excrement across the heavily fortified border as what it called “gifts of sincerity” Seoul responded angrily, calling the move base and dangerous.South Korea’s Defence Minister Shin Won-sik said during a meeting with US Defence Secretary Austin Lloyd on the sidelines of the Shangri-La security dialogue in Singapore on Sunday that the balloons violated the armistice agreement, according to South Korea's military.The two reaffirmed a coordinated response to any North Korean threats and provocations based on the South Korea-US. alliance’s combined defence posture, it added.Emergency alerts were issued in North Gyeongsang and Gangwon provinces and some parts of Seoul on Sunday, urging people not to come into contact with the balloons and to alert police.South Korea’s National Security Council standing committee will meet on Sunday afternoon to discuss whether to resume blasting loudspeakers at North Korea in response to the trash balloons, Yonhap news agency reported, citing the presidential office.

title: Delhi's temperature reading of 52.9 degrees Celsius was not accurate and was actually three degrees higher than the real temperature.
content:
New Delhi's recorded temperature of 52.9°C (127.22°F) was actually 3°C too high due to a sensor error.

The actual highest temperature was likely around 49°C (120.2°F), still breaking the city's previous record of 48.4°C (119.12°F) set in 1998.

The error has been fixed, and other weather stations in the city confirmed the extreme heat, with temperatures reaching 49°C (120.2°F) and 49.1°C (120.38°F).

Severe heat has caused deaths in some parts of India, with at least 33 people dying from suspected heatstroke on Friday.
summary: Unusually high temperature sensor error in Delhi reports a 52.9° Celsius temperature, but other stations indicate a new record high of 49.1° Celsius, causing heat-related deaths in India.

title: India holds final round of elections, with Prime Minister Modi and opposition leader Rahul Gandhi vying for victory.
content: India recently held a general election, with Prime Minister Modi and his challengers both expressing confidence in winning. Over a billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase election, which focused on issues like inequality and religion. The final phase saw over 100 million people registered to vote in several states. Modi is seeking a third term as Prime Minister for his BJP party, facing an alliance of 24 opposition parties. Despite Modi being widely expected to win a majority, the opposition alliance has put up a strong campaign, raising some doubts about the ease of his victory. Extreme heat and voter fatigue have also been factors, with nearly two dozen election officials dying of suspected heatstroke. Exit polls are expected to provide insights after the vote, but their accuracy has been questionable in the past. Modi initially focused on his achievements but later shifted to targeting the opposition by accusing them of favoring Muslims. The opposition has emphasized affirmative action and protecting the constitution from what they perceive as Modi's authoritarian rule.
summary: India's seven-phase general election culminates in its final stage, with polls held in 57 seats amid record summer heat and high voter expectations, as both incumbent Prime Minister Narendra Modi and opposition challengers predict victory.

title: Unauthorized translation and illegal copying of foreign books are common in Nepal. This deprives authors of fair compensation and undermines intellectual property rights.
content:
**Unauthorized Book Translations in Nepal**

Nepali publishers often translate books without permission from authors or publishers. This includes works by Taslima Nasrin, Steve Jobs, and others.

**Consequences of Unauthorized Translations**

* Authors and publishers lose income (royalties)
* Readers may be misled by poor-quality translations

**Factors Contributing to Piracy**

* Lack of contact between Nepali publishers and foreign publishers
* No agency to regulate translation quality
* Government tax policy in 2019 increased book import costs, leading to increased piracy

**Legal Implications**

* Translating and publishing books without permission is a crime under Nepal's Copyright Act
* Copyright violations are punishable by the government

**Solutions**

* Increased awareness of copyright laws
* Government action to seize pirated books
* Collaboration between government, publishers, authors, and readers
* Amendment of the Copyright Act to give more autonomy to the registrar's office
summary: Unauthorized translations of popular international books, including those by Taslima Nasrin, have flooded Nepal's book market, harming authors, publishers, and readers, while also tarnishing Nepal's reputation as piracy proliferates due to the lack of regulation and economic factors.

title: desperate-youths-from-maoist-heartland-hit-us-wall
content:
**Illegal US Migration in Former Maoist Base Areas**

**Problem:**
Many youths from remote villages in Rukum East and Dang have illegally traveled to the US through "backdoor routes." Some have returned empty-handed after being deported and losing significant amounts of money (up to Rs 45 million total).

**Reasons for Migration:**
* Poverty and lack of economic opportunities in the villages
* Influence of organized human traffickers
* Loans taken at high interest rates (up to 36%)

**Consequences:**
* Financial ruin for deported youths
* Mental health issues for deportees
* Depletion of village populations as youths leave
* Pressure on families and creditors
* Lack of political will and legal remedies to address the issue

**Specific Cases:**
* Ram Budha, deported after 27 months in a detention camp, owes over Rs 6 million in debt.
* Dhanlal Gharti, deported after 4 years in detention, faces an insurmountable financial crisis.
* Tikaram Pun, deported after 24 months in detention, suffers from mental health problems and is under pressure to repay a Rs 9.2 million loan.

**Impact on Village Life:**
* Loss of young people and potential laborers
* Weakening of village communities
* Erosion of Maoist ideology as former rebels turn to human traffickers

* Lack of specific laws to address illegal human trafficking

title: Poor patients in many countries are unable to access private hospital beds because they cannot afford the high costs.
content:
**Private Hospitals Ignoring Rules in Nepal**

Private hospitals in Nepal are not following the rules that require them to provide free services to poor patients. This has led to many people being unable to afford medical care.

**Lack of Monitoring**

Government agencies responsible for monitoring private hospitals are not doing their job, which allows them to ignore the rules.

**Hospitals Not Following Rules**

Hospitals in Pokhara, Chitwan, Biratnagar, and Butwal have all been found to be ignoring the rules. Hospitals claim to offer discounts, but often cannot provide proof.

**Patients Being Denied Treatment**

People like Gyanumaya BK have had to pay large amounts of money for medical care because hospitals refused to provide free services or discounts.

**Legal Actions Needed**

Government officials say that legal actions should be taken against hospitals that break the rules.
summary: Gyanumaya BK, a 69-year-old laborer, has incurred over Rs50,000 in medical expenses due to negligence by Pokhara's Metrocity Hospital, which failed to adhere to government regulations requiring private hospitals to provide free services to the underprivileged.

title: Extreme heat refers to unusually high temperatures that can be dangerous for people and the environment. It can cause heat-related illnesses such as heatstroke and dehydration, and can lead to wildfires, drought, and crop failures. Extreme heat events are becoming more frequent and intense due to climate change. Taking precautions to stay cool and hydrated is important during periods of extreme heat.
content:
**Extreme Heat Waves**

**Problem:**
* India and Mexico are facing deadly heat waves.
* Temperatures are reaching record highs, causing animal deaths, health issues, and water shortages.

**Cause:**
* Global warming is making heat waves more intense and frequent.
* The human body has a limit on how much heat it can handle.

**Consequences:**
* Heat can kill people, especially in vulnerable areas.
* It can also disrupt daily life, causing health problems, water shortages, and work interruptions.

**What's Next:**
* We need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to stop global warming and prevent even worse heat waves.
* We need to develop better warning systems and heat adaptation strategies.
* We need to protect wildlife from extreme heat.
summary: Amidst a global heatwave that has broken records in India, Mexico, and Europe, scientists warn that rising temperatures are rapidly approaching a critical limit for human survival, necessitating further research and immediate climate action to mitigate its catastrophic effects on individuals, ecosystems, and societies.

title:
**Constitution, Coalition, and Instability**

* **Constitution:** Rules and principles that govern a country.
* **Coalition:** Group of political parties that join together to form a government.

Coalitions can lead to instability in a country because:

* Different parties in the coalition may have different goals and priorities.
* Coalition governments may lack a clear majority, making it difficult to pass legislation.
* Coalitions can be fragile and can break up easily.
content:
- Politicians in Nepal blame the 2015 constitution for government instability.

- But a multi-party coalition government does not mean instability.

- Germany, Israel, and India have had stable coalition governments.

- A single-party government does not guarantee stability or economic progress.

- North Korea's stable single-party government has not led to economic success.

- A single-party majority can be dangerous if the leader uses it for personal gain.

- Instead of blaming the constitution, we should focus on the leaders who implement it.

- Respect for the constitution and democratic norms is essential for stability.

- The current leaders, Deuba, Oli, and Dahal, are responsible for government instability.
summary: Politicians blame Nepal's instability on the 2015 constitution, advocating for a one-party government by eliminating proportional representation, despite evidence demonstrating that coalition governments elsewhere have not hindered stability.

title:

Using evidence and critical thinking to:

title: Not safe to drink
content:
**Lack of Safe Drinking Water in Kathmandu**

* Bottled and jarred water is often contaminated with harmful particles.
* Government has failed to provide safe water despite Nepal's rich water resources.
* Budget cuts limit water testing, leading to more water-borne diseases.
* Public pollution and climate change contribute to water contamination.
* Government neglects human-made water safety issues.
* Water suppliers need training on water quality standards.
* Safe drinking water is a basic right and people need to protect their own health.
* Government and health officials should promote water treatment and storage methods.
summary: Despite Nepal's water abundance, bottled water contamination, inadequate water testing, and climate change-induced water contamination continue to plague Kathmandu Valley, leaving residents without access to safe drinking water.

title: Supporting local initiatives and individuals directly, rather than relying on large organizations or government programs.
content:
In Nepal, many rural villages lack basic amenities like water, transportation, and communication. Despite the federal system's goal of improving infrastructure, these areas still struggle.

People in some villages must travel hours to fetch water or collect government allowances. This shows that remote areas need improved roads, internet, and basic services like healthcare and education.

To solve this, local governments should focus on developing villages by improving services within wards. They can also use mobile teams to provide services and work with provincial governments to make service delivery more efficient.

It is crucial to retain people in villages to prevent depopulation due to migration.
summary: Despite the establishment of a federal system in Nepal aiming to improve infrastructure in remote areas, many villages still lack basic amenities such as drinking water and access to social security allowances due to inadequate decentralization and poor infrastructure.

title: People are now supporting authoritarian leaders who have been democratically elected.
content:
**Human rights are declining globally** with restrictions on free speech, assembly, women's rights, and economic equality. Armed conflict deaths are rising.

**South Asia is no exception:** Nepal and Sri Lanka have seen shrinking civic space, weaponized laws to curb online speech, and excessive force against protesters.

**Factors driving the decline:**

* Economic inequality
* Covid-19
* Authoritarianism, even among democratically elected leaders
* Attacks on minorities and vulnerable groups

**Amnesty International is concerned about the arrest of media owner Rohit Sirohiya:** The charges are politically motivated to silence dissent and restrict freedom of the press.

**Unregulated artificial intelligence (AI) poses risks:**

* Discrimination and bias in data
* Mass surveillance
* Cyber surveillance and spyware

**Nepal's transitional justice process is stalled:**

* Fear of upsetting peace by pursuing justice
* Categorization of crimes as serious and non-serious
* Lack of independence, transparency, and political interference

**Call to action:**

* Governments must act to protect human rights
* Regulate AI responsibly
* Advance transitional justice in Nepal by following Supreme Court directives
* International community must support Nepal and other vulnerable countries facing climate change
summary: Amnesty International's Secretary General voiced concerns about human rights backsliding globally, highlighting shrinking civic space, overbroad digital laws, and government attacks on dissent in Nepal and Sri Lanka.

title: If Oli does not stop his political maneuvers, other political groups may come together to form coalitions against him.
content: The CPN (Unified Socialist), which was fashioned in 2021 by a splinter faction of the CPN-UML, is preparing to hold its first general convention. The party has done poorly in all elections since its establishment. It has also failed in service delivery despite continuously being in the government since its inception. The Post’s Thira Lal Bhusal caught up with the party’s General Secretary, Ghanashyam Bhusal, for insights about the Unified Socialist’s upcoming general convention and broader political dynamics. Your party is holding its first general convention in a few weeks. What new things does the party have to offer?Our party was born in the context of sharp division between political forces over the issue of Parliament dissolution by then prime minister KP Sharma Oli, chairman of the CPN-UML, which was then also our party. That was the immediate reason for the party split. But there were other disputes within the UML. The differences were about the political line and party orientation. After Oli’s election as the party leader, policy issues were undermined. In fact, we were at odds because of the policy issues.What were those policy disputes?We [our faction] believed that after the establishment of democratic republic system, the fight for a political system was almost over as this is the most progressive political system of our time. We stressed that now the political line and programmes of the party should be updated and the focus shifted to attaining prosperity. Democracy can’t be sustained if we can’t promote industry, create jobs and ensure good governance. So we have to orient our policies to ensure these achievements. In our country, comprador capitalists, who want to earn money without running industries, are dominant. They shift the state’s policies in collusion with politicians, bureaucrats, police and other state agencies. Likewise, the economic policy doesn’t talk about jobs and production but only growth and development. These factors are detrimental to our economy. We wanted to change these policies and dynamics. We had differences on these issues with Oli. When we were debating them with him, the Parliament dissolution created a sort of abnormal situation. We stood against it, defying our party chief Oli. That division eventually led to the party split. Many people, including leaders in our own party, saw Parliament dissolution as the only reason behind the birth of our party. The new party was confused about the way forward. The upcoming general convention will formulate clear policies in this connection. What about the leadership? Will the party get new leadership?For the past two decades, I have been advocating that a communist party should adopt the right programmes to bring about social changes. At the time, the Maoists had a policy of seizing state power through force, and the UML was talking only about transforming society through elections. But the UML was basically engaged only in winning elections. In this context, we [a group of UML leaders] came up with some policies that would make substantive changes in such ritualistic practices.Now, I have been saying that our party should be led by a leader who can internalise and effectively implement those policies. We have almost finalised the party’s policy documents. When the documents are circulated among party workers, the debate about who is eligible to implement these policies will start.You often claim to be the proponent of the CPN (Unified Socialist)’s party line. If so, will you claim party leadership to implement those policies?The first condition to become the party leader is that he/she should internalise the policies and programmes adopted by the party. I shouldn’t say that no one besides me has internalised them. It is true that I have been actively leading the debates and discussions to introduce new policies in the party. Party representatives will debate and decide this at the convention.A large number of senior leaders quit the UML to form this party. But it couldn’t even retain its members let alone further expand.There was a need for radical reforms and restructuring in communist organisations and their policies. This should have been done by the country’s largest communist party—the CPN-UML. But the party leadership and its rank and file didn’t realise the need for it. There was no serious policy discussion in the UML. While the leadership of the CPN (Unified Socialist) and its organisation are oriented in the right direction, it’s not properly trained for such restructuring. Therefore, many even accused the party leadership of being just a follower and subservient to the Nepali Congress and the Maoist Centre. Various sections of society who had praised us for standing against Oli’s wrong decision didn’t appreciate other political moves of our party. Parliament dissolution was a political event. A party needs clear programmes and agenda to keep public support. Unfortunately, we were found wanting in this regard. We should have done something in job creation and increasing production. We will make such things clear at the upcoming convention. Since its formation, the party has been constantly bickered over power sharing with other parties and even party leaders always seem to be wrangling for ministerial berths. Don’t you think such activities weaken the party?This happened as the party lacked clear policies to move ahead. Standing against Oli became sort of its policy as there was deep resentment against him. As far as the leaders’ attachment to power is concerned, the party was born out of power [from Parliament, not from the ground]. So the struggle for power is linked to its genesis. It has been in power ever since its establishment. These allegations were hence natural, and the party leadership couldn’t clarify things. We couldn’t show what we did for the betterment of the society.Party chair Madhav Kumar Nepal and other top leader Jhalanath Khanal seem to be working at cross-purposes. Nepal seems closer to the Congress while Khanal has been consistently lobbying for an alliance with the UML and the Maoist Centre.We have almost resolved this issue in the course of finalising the party’s policy document. Our conclusion is that, in general, the Congress mainly represents neoliberals and comprador capitalists. When we lobby for the country’s independent economic policy, the Congress may not agree. The party tilts more towards pro-western ideas in the name of liberalism. We in our party are in consensus that in the long-run we will compete against the Congress. But we shouldn’t forget that we got the current democratic system and the constitution only after fighting jointly with the Congress. So we have to keep our doors open for collaboration with the Congress in order to safeguard this system and the constitution. It is also historically proven that the Congress and left forces should stand together to safeguard democratic system. Thus we have now made our theoretical standing clearer.But in practical aspects, as you said, there are some differences. Party chair doesn’t want to increase distance with the Congress as he worked closely with Congress President Sher Bahadur Deuba and other leaders to fight Oli ji. But Jhalanath Khanal ji is for left alliance.While there are already major communist forces such as the CPN-UML and the Maoist Centre, why is one more communist force, CPN (Unified Socialist), needed? How do you prove your relevance?The CPN-UML didn’t follow the right policies, even those endorsed by its general conventions. Party chief Oli wants total control of the party organisation, from the centre to the local units. The entire party is mobilised mainly to realise Oli’s personal ambitions. This party can’t work in favour of the society in the long run. The Maoist Centre hasn’t succeeded in transforming itself from war-era rigidity of Maoism. The Unified Socialist is here to correct these two major deviations of Nepal’s communist movement. Had the party raised this issue prominently right since its formation, people would have understood its relevance. We will do it now. This convention will be a landmark event in this connection as well. Many people think that the Unified Socialist will ultimately merge with the UML.Merger is not a solution. Even if you want to bring two parties together, you have to unify them. A merger brings top leaders together based on power sharing, just like the merger of the UML and Maoist Centre in 2018. Such a merger is guided mainly by the interests of certain leaders. That’s why the merger didn’t last. The need now is unification among communist parties based on policies and programmes. Otherwise, it will be nothing more than a gathering of leaders. There is no point in merging the party to make the UML bigger and make Oli prime minister one more time.As a leader of a ruling coalition partner, how confident are you of the stability of this alliance?Given the composition of the present Parliament, we can’t rule out the making and breaking of different coalitions until the next election. Oli ji used to talk of the Unified Socialist as a tumour removed after a surgery. His mindset that he can do anything in Nepali politics has suffered a setback. Therefore, he became ready for this coalition. If he has realised this change, this coalition will last. But if he again tries to manoeuvre to justify his dissolution of Parliament and serve any other interests, there might even be other coalitions.Why has your party been in a state of disharmony with coalition partners right from the beginning?Initially, the prime minister didn’t consult with us while making this coalition. That created misunderstanding. He eventually admitted his mistake in failing to inform us on time and sought our support. So, that chapter was closed. Now we have no issue at the party’s level, and officially, we are committed to this coalition.

They shift the state’s policies in collusion with politicians, bureaucrats, police and other state agencies. Likewise, the economic policy doesn’t talk about jobs and production but only growth and development. These factors are detrimental to our economy. We wanted to change these policies and dynamics. We had differences on these issues with Oli. When we were debating them with him, the Parliament dissolution created a sort of abnormal situation. We stood against it, defying our party chief Oli. That division eventually led to the party split. Many people, including leaders in our own party, saw Parliament dissolution as the only reason behind the birth of our party. The new party was confused about the way forward. The upcoming general convention will formulate clear policies in this connection. What about the leadership? Will the party get new leadership?For the past two decades, I have been advocating that a communist party should adopt the right programmes to bring about social changes. At the time, the Maoists had a policy of seizing state power through force, and the UML was talking only about transforming society through elections. But the UML was basically engaged only in winning elections. In this context, we [a group of UML leaders] came up with some policies that would make substantive changes in such ritualistic practices.Now, I have been saying that our party should be led by a leader who can internalise and effectively implement those policies. We have almost finalised the party’s policy documents. When the documents are circulated among party workers, the debate about who is eligible to implement these policies will start.You often claim to be the proponent of the CPN (Unified Socialist)’s party line. If so, will you claim party leadership to implement those policies?The first condition to become the party leader is that he/she should internalise the policies and programmes adopted by the party. I shouldn’t say that no one besides me has internalised them. It is true that I have been actively leading the debates and discussions to introduce new policies in the party. Party representatives will debate and decide this at the convention.A large number of senior leaders quit the UML to form this party. But it couldn’t even retain its members let alone further expand.There was a need for radical reforms and restructuring in communist organisations and their policies. This should have been done by the country’s largest communist party—the CPN-UML. But the party leadership and its rank and file didn’t realise the need for it. There was no serious policy discussion in the UML. While the leadership of the CPN (Unified Socialist) and its organisation are oriented in the right direction, it’s not properly trained for such restructuring. Therefore, many even accused the party leadership of being just a follower and subservient to the Nepali Congress and the Maoist Centre. Various sections of society who had praised us for standing against Oli’s wrong decision didn’t appreciate other political moves of our party. Parliament dissolution was a political event. A party needs clear programmes and agenda to keep public support. Unfortunately, we were found wanting in this regard. We should have done something in job creation and increasing production. We will make such things clear at the upcoming convention. Since its formation, the party has been constantly bickered over power sharing with other parties and even party leaders always seem to be wrangling for ministerial berths. Don’t you think such activities weaken the party?This happened as the party lacked clear policies to move ahead. Standing against Oli became sort of its policy as there was deep resentment against him. As far as the leaders’ attachment to power is concerned, the party was born out of power [from Parliament, not from the ground]. So the struggle for power is linked to its genesis. It has been in power ever since its establishment. These allegations were hence natural, and the party leadership couldn’t clarify things. We couldn’t show what we did for the betterment of the society.Party chair Madhav Kumar Nepal and other top leader Jhalanath Khanal seem to be working at cross-purposes. Nepal seems closer to the Congress while Khanal has been consistently lobbying for an alliance with the UML and the Maoist Centre.We have almost resolved this issue in the course of finalising the party’s policy document. Our conclusion is that, in general, the Congress mainly represents neoliberals and comprador capitalists. When we lobby for the country’s independent economic policy, the Congress may not agree. The party tilts more towards pro-western ideas in the name of liberalism. We in our party are in consensus that in the long-run we will compete against the Congress. But we shouldn’t forget that we got the current democratic system and the constitution only after fighting jointly with the Congress. So we have to keep our doors open for collaboration with the Congress in order to safeguard this system and the constitution. It is also historically proven that the Congress and left forces should stand together to safeguard democratic system. Thus we have now made our theoretical standing clearer.But in practical aspects, as you said, there are some differences. Party chair doesn’t want to increase distance with the Congress as he worked closely with Congress President Sher Bahadur Deuba and other leaders to fight Oli ji. But Jhalanath Khanal ji is for left alliance.While there are already major communist forces such as the CPN-UML and the Maoist Centre, why is one more communist force, CPN (Unified Socialist), needed? How do you prove your relevance?The CPN-UML didn’t follow the right policies, even those endorsed by its general conventions. Party chief Oli wants total control of the party organisation, from the centre to the local units. The entire party is mobilised mainly to realise Oli’s personal ambitions. This party can’t work in favour of the society in the long run. The Maoist Centre hasn’t succeeded in transforming itself from war-era rigidity of Maoism. The Unified Socialist is here to correct these two major deviations of Nepal’s communist movement. Had the party raised this issue prominently right since its formation, people would have understood its relevance. We will do it now. This convention will be a landmark event in this connection as well. Many people think that the Unified Socialist will ultimately merge with the UML.Merger is not a solution. Even if you want to bring two parties together, you have to unify them. A merger brings top leaders together based on power sharing, just like the merger of the UML and Maoist Centre in 2018. Such a merger is guided mainly by the interests of certain leaders. That’s why the merger didn’t last. The need now is unification among communist parties based on policies and programmes. Otherwise, it will be nothing more than a gathering of leaders. There is no point in merging the party to make the UML bigger and make Oli prime minister one more time.As a leader of a ruling coalition partner, how confident are you of the stability of this alliance?Given the composition of the present Parliament, we can’t rule out the making and breaking of different coalitions until the next election. Oli ji used to talk of the Unified Socialist as a tumour removed after a surgery. His mindset that he can do anything in Nepali politics has suffered a setback. Therefore, he became ready for this coalition. If he has realised this change, this coalition will last. But if he again tries to manoeuvre to justify his dissolution of Parliament and serve any other interests, there might even be other coalitions.Why has your party been in a state of disharmony with coalition partners right from the beginning?Initially, the prime minister didn’t consult with us while making this coalition. That created misunderstanding. He eventually admitted his mistake in failing to inform us on time and sought our support. So, that chapter was closed. Now we have no issue at the party’s level, and officially, we are committed to this coalition.

**UN Resident Coordinator in Nepal: Hanaa Singer-Hamdy**

**Role of the UN in Nepal**

* Supports Nepal's development and peace efforts.

**Progress and Challenges for Nepal**

* Progress: Reduced poverty, maternal and child mortality, increased life expectancy, and improved infrastructure.
* Challenges: Poverty and inequality, climate change, and LDC graduation requirements.

**Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)**

* Nepal has made significant progress towards SDGs.
* Challenges: Data gaps, financing gaps (11% of GDP).
* UN supports Nepal to achieve SDGs through technical assistance and partnerships.

**Nepal Investment Summit**

* UN played a role in organizing and promoting the summit.
* Aims to attract investment and support Nepal's LDC graduation.

**Encouraging Development Partner Investment**

* UN encourages development partners to invest in Nepal.
* Focus on catalytic sectors that accelerate SDG achievement.
* Blended finance approaches can leverage resources and reduce financing gaps.

**UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF)**

* UN's partnership framework with Nepal.
* Focuses on four strategic priorities:
    * Sustainable economic transformation
    * Inclusive human development
    * Environmental sustainability
    * Effective governance with federalism and inclusion

**Climate Change and Disaster Resilience**

* UN supports Nepal's efforts to mitigate climate change and build resilience.
* Focus on empowering marginalized groups and promoting sustainable livelihoods.

**Peace Process and Transitional Justice**

* UN supports Nepal's efforts to conclude the peace process.
* Encourages inclusive and victim-centric transitional justice.

**Nepal's Role in Global Forums**

* Nepal plays a significant role in global forums like the UN, LDC bureau, and Human Rights Council.
* Champions mountain agenda and advocates for LDC interests.

**Addressing Multilateralism and Polarization**

* UN promotes international norms and standards.
* Summit of the Future aims to enhance cooperation and address challenges.
summary: In 2023, the UN Resident Coordinator Hanaa Singer-Hamdy, returning to Nepal, highlights Nepal's social and economic progress, including the achievement of SDGs, while recognizing challenges in poverty reduction, inequality, climate change, and securing funding for sustainable development.

**Budget Session of Nepal's Parliament**

* Starts without resolving differences over forming a committee to investigate fraud allegations against Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane.
* Minister Giri hopes opposition will agree to a broader study of the cooperative sector instead of focusing on Lamichhane.
* Government aims to prioritize 24 bills, including the Enforced Disappearances Act amendment and the school education bill.
* Minister Giri acknowledges the need for broader consultation in bill drafting and promises to engage more stakeholders.
* Transitional Justice Act amendment bill nears finalization, but issues of murder classification and sentencing remain.
* Committee to recommend office bearers for transitional justice commissions faces objections, but Minister Giri insists it must follow the Supreme Court's order.
* Appointment of Supreme Court justices expected soon.
* No discussion on amending the constitution to revisit the electoral system, but the need for greater stability is recognized.
* No current discussions about a possible alliance between the UML and Congress.
summary: The budget session of the federal parliament begins without resolution on forming an investigation committee, while the government plans to prioritize bill endorsement and facilitate a productive session.

title: Muluki Ain is a set of laws in Nepal that governs various aspects of life, including civil and criminal matters.
content: The Muluki Ain, a landmark Nepalese legal code, was created to establish a fair and organized legal system. It did not focus solely on supporting the caste system, but also established the rule of law, defined the powers of government officials, and recognized the need for reforms to address injustices in the caste system. The code is based on traditional shastras and customs, but also provides for future reforms to ensure equal treatment under the law.
summary: Muluki Ain, a 19th-century legal code, rationalized judicial structure, codified common law, recognized rule of law, and acknowledged need for caste system reforms despite its caste-based divisions.

title: Misleading news is information that is presented as true but contains false or distorted information, often intended to deceive people for various reasons, such as political gain or financial benefit. It can be intentional or unintentional and can spread quickly through social media or traditional media. Misleading-news can erode trust in the media and make it difficult for people to find accurate information.

title: Misunderstanding occurs when people interpret something incorrectly, resulting in a different understanding from what was intended. It can be caused by different communication styles, cultural differences, preconceived notions, or a lack of clear communication. Misunderstandings can lead to conflicts, hurt feelings, and missed opportunities. To avoid misunderstandings, it's essential to communicate clearly, actively listen, and be open to different perspectives.

**Japan-Nepal Work Agreement Summary**

Japan needs foreign workers and many Nepalis want to work in Japan.

The agreement between Japan and Nepal does not require a government-to-government process for hiring.

Nepali workers and Japanese employers sign the employment contract.

Private job agencies can help Nepalis find jobs in Japan.

Japanese companies may not always pay for airfare, insurance, or medical exams.

Japan has similar work agreements with other South Asian countries.

The hope is that qualified Nepalis can find jobs and travel to Japan smoothly.
summary: Japan opened its labor market to Nepali specified skilled workers in 2019, but misunderstandings about the agreement have hindered Nepali workers from finding jobs in Japan.

content: I am very grateful to Deepak Thapa for raising concerns about the fate of Nepali studies in Euro-America, and for his kind words about my own work over the years (‘Nepali language at SOAS’, November 25). I would like to add that much of what we achieved at SOAS University of London would not have been possible without the contribution of my colleague Krishna Pradhan. Pradhan taught Nepali at SOAS for 15 years until his own early retirement in 2019, and was greatly admired by the many students who learned so much from him. His presence at SOAS also enabled me to develop courses in Nepali literature, history and culture alongside the essential language courses. Sadly, none of this will be available to future generations of students in the UK.Michael Hutt,Emeritus Professor of Nepali and Himalayan Studies,SOAS, University of London

title: chhaupadi-persists
content: While feminine issues are addressed every now and then, not everything is taken seriously, and the unspoken issues go unnoticed. Here, I’m not only addressing the horrendous issue of Chhaupadi itself but also speaking of those women and girls who fall prey to this absurd menstrual practice.Ever thought what travelling back in time would feel like? Many in Nepal do not have to imagine, as such old and evil practises continue to occur in the 21st century!Chhaupadi is a flawed tradition connected to the taboo surrounding menstruation that prohibits Hindu menstruators from participating in normal family activities while on their period, as they are considered impure. Although it is said to be practised in the rural part of the country, it does exist in urban areas, too. Going back to its roots, we could perhaps rationalise that women were asked to stay cautious when menstruating because humans were closely surrounded by wildlife. The stench of blood during their period may have made them more vulnerable to attacks from these animals. But even this absurd line of thought doesn't make much sense anymore. The practise was made illegal in 2005, but cases related to it were reported as recent as 2019. News headlines vouched for fatalities on this account. But why are there such trivial punishments for such an offence? Shouldn’t the punishments be rethought to strongly discourage Chhaupadi altogether?Moreover, the reported cases are just the tip of the iceberg. The more you look into it, there are bound to be cases that have gone unreported because nothing immediately tragic occurred. This letter is a call for all of us to come together to fight this social plague. While the legal implications of such an offence are ambiguous, let's collectively decide that the societal implications of it will be grave. Let's refuse to accept such atrocities for our mothers, sisters and, above all, ourselves.Gauri Tandon, via email
